thank you ken, I will look through these papers.

but as far as I can see i=
t, it seems there is no apparent consensus on how the input information in =
a sequence learning / prediction task should look like to reflect more real=
istic conditions (such as navigating through a maze or performing a complex=
 motor sequence). 

Best,
Martin

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Ken" <kstan=
ley@...> wrote:
>
> 
> 
> Hi Martin, I think a helpful reference in this ar=
ea is J=FCrgen Schmidhuber's work on memory in recurrent neural networks, w=
hich includes writings on sequence learning:
> 
> http://www.idsia.ch/~juer=
gen/rnn.html
> 
> His "deep memory" papers (also shown on that page) also m=
ight be relevant and give you ideas.
> 
> While most of the work there does=
 not involve evolution (though some does), it does show you the kinds of ta=
sks that have been attempted in sequence learning and memory in general.
> =

> ken
>
